identity.biochemicalTests: Gram-positive club-shaped rod with metachromatic granules (Albert's stain), catalase +, non-motile, urease â€“, nitrate reduction +, glucose and maltose fermentation +. Elek test or PCR for toxin production.

clinicalProfile.summary: Corynebacterium diphtheriae is the causative agent of diphtheria, a serious bacterial infection affecting the mucous membranes of the throat and nose. Toxigenic strains produce a powerful exotoxin that can cause a thick, gray membrane (pseudomembrane) to form in the throat, leading to breathing difficulties, as well as systemic effects like myocarditis and neuropathy.
pathophysiologyPearls: The major virulence factor is the diphtheria toxin, an A-B exotoxin that inhibits protein synthesis in host cells, leading to tissue necrosis.
The pseudomembrane is composed of fibrin, dead host cells, inflammatory cells, and bacteria, and can cause airway obstruction.
keySignsAndSymptoms: Adherent gray pseudomembrane on the pharynx, tonsils, or larynx

clinicalSyndromes.description: The most common form, characterized by pharyngitis or laryngitis with the formation of a pseudomembrane. Can be anterior nasal, pharyngeal, or laryngeal.
Presents as chronic, non-healing skin ulcers, which may also have a gray membrane. Systemic complications are less common than with respiratory diphtheria.
Rarely, C. diphtheriae can cause invasive infections like endocarditis, septic arthritis, and osteomyelitis.

highRiskPopulations: Individuals living in crowded or unsanitary conditions
Travelers to regions where diphtheria is endemic
transmissionVectors: Direct contact with respiratory secretions or skin lesions
prognosisNotes: Case fatality rate is 5-10%, with higher rates in the very young and the elderly.
Myocarditis and neuropathy are the most common severe complications.

generalNotes: Treatment involves both diphtheria antitoxin to neutralize the exotoxin and antibiotics to eradicate the bacteria.
See specific guidelines for Pharyngitis, Diphtheria for detailed treatment regimens.

adjunctiveTherapies.details: Crucial for neutralizing unbound toxin and should be administered as early as possible based on clinical suspicion.

testingIndications: Clinical suspicion of diphtheria (sore throat with an adherent membrane).

specialTests.purpose: To isolate C. diphtheriae from a throat swab or piece of the pseudomembrane. Requires special selective media like Tinsdale agar or tellurite agar.
An in vitro immunodiffusion test to determine if the isolated strain is toxigenic.
A molecular method to detect the gene encoding the diphtheria toxin.

diagnosticNotes.summary: Definitive diagnosis is made by isolating C. diphtheriae in culture from a clinical specimen and demonstrating toxin production.
diagnosticNotes.biosafetyWarning: Laboratory personnel should be notified of the suspicion of diphtheria to ensure proper handling of specimens.

methods.details: Requires selective media (e.g., Tinsdale agar) and can take several days.

preventionAndScreening.details: Active immunization with diphtheria toxoid-containing vaccines (e.g., DTaP, Tdap, Td) is the most effective means of prevention. See specific vaccine guidelines for schedules.

guidelineReferences.summaryOrNote: Provides comprehensive information on diphtheria diagnosis, treatment, and prevention.
